review_comments.body:
How do you feel about `LogicProgramming.jl`?

`Logic.jl` is also available.

author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->
Usually Julia is not referenced in the name, maybe Prolog.jl would be a better name and fit better with the guidlines?

@fredrikekre Thanks for the suggestion! I thought about it myself, but I think Prolog.jl would imply this package supports all standard Prolog features and syntax, or is an interface to an external Prolog engine, neither of which this package provides.

> How do you feel about `LogicProgramming.jl`?
> 
> `Logic.jl` is also available.

I was considering `Logic.jl`, but decided that both of them would be too general. There are other logic programming languages like [`miniKanren`](https://github.com/latticetower/MuKanren.jl), and so I didn't want to take up namespace in the registry with something as specific as a Prolog-variant. 

I like `Julog` because it communicates that it is Prolog-based, while not exactly being Prolog. It follows the pattern of other Prolog variants, like Datalog, Problog, AnsProlog, etc. It also makes for a convenient macro name for parsing logical formulas. `@julog` is memorable and short, doesn't clash with `@prolog` (which is a macro this package provides to parse Prolog strings directly, though it doesn't handle full Prolog syntax), and is specific enough that it is unlikely to clash with other packages (whereas a macro like `@logic` seems much more likely to do that).
Ultimately it’s up to you I guess.
I would recommend a name without `Ju` or `Julia` in it, but it’s your package, so if you really want to keep this name, let me know, and I’ll merge this PR.
@DilumAluthge Gotcha -- I appreciate the spirit of the guidelines, but all things considered, I'd like to stick with `Julog` as the name for the reasons I've mentioned. Thanks for understanding!
